Describe the problem:
I've written an adapter that extends the FirestoreRecyclerAdapter. My RecyclerView uses the adapter to display items. The adapter uses a query that is ordered by a boolean field named 'checkedIn'. The adapter also uses a custom parser that implements SnapshotParser. When I'm binding the data to my viewHolder, I use the value of checkedIn to set the background color of the item. I think everything that I'm doing is typical.
Here are the situations where I'm having trouble:
(1) When the value of checkedIn is changed on a document (for example: checkedIn goes from true to false), the FirestoreRecyclerAdapter 'hears' the change but treats it as a 'MOVE' instead of a both a 'MOVE' and a 'CHANGE'. The consequence of it being treated as only a 'MOVE' is that onBindViewHolder() never gets called and it never gets a chance to update the background color of the item. In the RecyclerView, the item does get moved. It's just the wrong color and contains the wrong data.
(2) The second situation relates to how the cache deals with moves that are also changes. If a MOVE ( with a CHANGE) comes through, the cache does not invalidate the old object in the cache. Consequently, the old cached object is passed to onBindViewHolder.

Expected Results:
I would expect onBindViewHolder to get called with the most current data whenever there is a change.

Relevant Code:
As a workaround on my local system, I've made the following changes:
For (1), I added a call to notifyItemChanged(newIndex) in the 'MOVED' case of FirestoreRecyclerAdapter.onChildChanged(). I placed it right after the existing call to  notifyItemMoved(oldIndex, newIndex);
For (2), I changed BaseObservableSnapshotArray.notifyOnChildChanged() to call mCachingParser.invalidate(snapshot) when the change type is MOVED. I realize that change undermines the effectiveness of the cache.
These two changes aren't ideal but they do resolve the problems I'm seeing. Could you recommend a better workaround or is this a bug?

issues.body:
`FirebaseRecyclerAdapter` is using `hashcode()` for [it's item id's](https://github.com/firebase/FirebaseUI-Android/blob/master/database/src/main/java/com/firebase/ui/database/FirebaseRecyclerAdapter.java#L176). The `hashcode()` of a key isn't a stable or unique id as required by `RecyclerView`. Multiple keys may produce the same `hashcode()`. As per `RecyclerView` docs:

> Return the stable ID for the item at position. If hasStableIds() would return false this method should return NO_ID. The default implementation of this method returns NO_ID.

The easiest fix is to remove the implementation, since `setHasStableIds()` isn't being called in the adapter. Stable ids help with RecyclerView animations though, so another approach is to fake an id by keeping a map of keys with their generated id's to ensure the stability of the ids when data is updated.
issues.title: Hashcode is not a stable id for FirebaseRecyclerAdapter

1. Check for a null email in `CredentialSignInHandler` and fail the sign in if the email is null.
2. Use `TwitterAuthClient#requestEmail` to show the request email activity.

I prefer solution 2 because we are being more transparent about requesting a user's email, but it requires more steps and a Twitter user might not have an email: https://docs.fabric.io/android/twitter/log-in-with-twitter.html#request-user-email-address

I'm using the AuthUI to login to an app I'm migrating to the new Firebase. The old login worked fine but the new one always stops with facebook or google.

Call:
`startActivityForResult(
                        AuthUI.getInstance(FirebaseApp.getInstance())
                                .createSignInIntentBuilder()
                                .setProviders(
                                        AuthUI.EMAIL_PROVIDER,
                                        AuthUI.GOOGLE_PROVIDER,
                                        AuthUI.FACEBOOK_PROVIDER)
                                .build(),
                        RC_SIGN_IN);
`
The spinner spins forever and the Activity never finishes. Back doesn't do anything.
![2016-05-19 00 20 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1415461/15379427/5c7e37a8-1d6d-11e6-87a9-91418c3894dd.png)

Using email works. 

I have setup FB app id & secret in the firebase console. The app has been migrated to the new firebase SDK.

There's no errors in console. 

Let me know if I can help you debug somehow to get more info to solve the situation. I know this might have too little info to track the issue.
